Context:
Program Name: Business Administration (with work experience)
Code: B155
Credential: Ontario College Advanced Diploma
Method of Study: Full-time
Duration: 3 years (6 semesters in-class, 2 semesters work experience)
Starting Months: January, September
Domestic Tuition: $4,663.00 *
International Tuition: $17,455.00 **
Centre: Business
School: Management
Location: St. James Campus
Experiential Learning: Work Experience (Co-op or Internship) Required
Semester 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6 Delivery: On Campus (for both Fall 2023 and Winter 2024)
Program Description: The Business Administration (with work experience) program at George Brown College in Toronto offers diverse career choices and opportunities in various business disciplines. Graduates are prepared to work in team settings and lead projects with relevant skills.
Learning Outcomes:
- Conduct and present research to support business decision-making
- Assess and use current concepts/systems and technologies to support an organization's business initiatives
- Develop a business plan to formulate the strategic direction of an organization
- Apply human resources practices to support management objectives and the organization's goals

* Domestic tuition is subject to change.
** International tuition is subject to change and does not include additional fees such as application fee, health insurance fee, etc.

Context: The Business program (B155) is part of George Brown College's School of Management. Students with work experience should apply to this program, while those without should apply to B145. George Brown College has earned international recognition from the Accreditation Council for Business Schools and Programs (ACBSP), making it one of only two colleges in Ontario with ACBSP accreditation. Centre for Business students are required to bring their own laptops due to a Bring Your Own Device (BYOD) initiative. The program requires completion of two semesters of work experience, which can be co-op (paid) or internship (unpaid). George Brown works with employers and industry partners to identify potential work experience opportunities, and students are encouraged to pursue self-directed industry work experience. Graduates are prepared for administrative and management positions in various employment settings, such as assistant manager, customer service representative, financial services representative, and project manager. International students are not eligible for optional co-op arrangements; for more information, they should consult the international student office. For field education opportunities and additional information, please contact the Centre for Business at business@georgebrown.ca.
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2023/Business Administration Program (with work experience) B155 | George Brown College2023.txt

Context:
To graduate from the B155 program, you are required to complete a total of 37 courses: 28 mandatory courses, 6 Business Electives, and 3 General Education Electives. You also need to complete 2 Work Experience Terms. These work experience terms can be co-op, internship, simulation, consulting or research projects. Depending on the results of your placement tests, you may be required to take COMM 1000 (Introduction to College Communication) and MATH 1027 (Business Math with Remediation) before progressing to certain courses. These courses do not count toward the 36 courses required for graduation and will be charged extra. You must complete three General Education courses from at least two of the following categories: Social Sciences, Arts and Humanities, or Science and Technology. It is necessary to make up any failed or dropped courses before graduating. Some Continuing Education courses may be taken in the evening to make up classes, but students should check with the business office staff to ensure they are equivalent to what is taught in the full-time program.

Program: B155
Total courses required for graduation: 37
Mandatory courses: 28
Business Electives: 6
General Education Electives: 3
Work Experience Terms: 2
Possible work experience terms: co-op, internship, simulation, consulting or research projects
Courses per semester: 5 (assuming Semester 1 and 2 have the same courses)
Total semesters: 6

Required courses for Semester 1:
- BUS 1038: Business Concepts I (NONE as prerequisite)
- COMM 2000: Communicating Across Contexts (NONE as prerequisite)
- COMP 1010: Business Computer Applications I (NONE as prerequisite)
- HRM 1008: Fundamentals of HR Management (NONE as prerequisite)
- MARK 1020: Principles of Marketing I (NONE as prerequisite)
- MATH 1008: Math for Business & Management I (NONE as prerequisite)

If there is no specific program name mentioned in the text, it's essential to return an empty text.

Context:
The text provides information about the courses offered in a graduate program at the college, along with their corresponding codes, and some details about the learning outcomes of the program. Here is the extracted information:

1. List of courses offered:
   - MMK 1114: Business Research & Report Writing
   - COMM 1034: Principles of E-Business
   - COMP 1113: Coaching for Effective Performance Management (by interview only)
   - HRM 2027: Coaching for Effective Performance Management
   - HRM 1008: Retail Math
   - MARK 2053: Negotiation Skills
   - MGMT 2037: Retail Management
   - MGMT 1017: Purchasing Practices
   - MGMT 4009: International Sales and Marketing
   - MGMT 2041: International Market Entry Strategies
   - BUS 1038: International Trade Management
   - MGMT 2029: International Trade Management
   - MATH 1138: Retail Math
   - MGMT 1034: Retail Marketing
   - MARK 1020: Shopper Research, Marketing, and Negotiation Skills
   - HRM 2030: Field-Based Advanced Coaching (by interview only)
   - MGMT 3013: Shopper Research

2. Program Learning Outcomes:
   - Evaluate the impact of global issues on an organization's business opportunities by using an environmental scan.
   - Apply principles of corporate sustainability, corporate social responsibility, and ethics to support an organization’s business initiatives.
   - Assess and use current concepts/systems and technologies to support an organization's business initiatives.
   - Conduct and present research to support business decision making.
   - Plan, implement, and evaluate projects by applying project management principles.
   - Perform work in compliance with relevant statutes, regulations, and business practices.
   - Apply human resource practices to support management objectives and the organization’s goals.
   - Use accounting and financial principles to support the management and operations of an organization.
   - Assess marketing and sales concepts and strategies and apply them to the needs of an organization.
   - Outline principles of supply chain management and operations management and assess their impact on the operations of an organization.
   - Participate in the development of a business plan.
   - Develop strategies for ongoing personal and professional development to enhance work performance in the business field.
   - Outline strategies used to manage risks in an organization's business activities.

3. Tuition & Fees:
   - Domestic Tuition: $4,663.00 *
   - International Tuition: $17,455.00 **

* The tuition amounts listed are for the first two semesters of programs starting in Fall 2022.
** Fees are subject to change.

Context:
Fees:
- Fall 2022: Subject to change for later dates. Total fees for first two semesters unknown.
- Fall 2023 and later: Tuition fees, materials, student service and ancillary fees for the first two semesters are listed below:
  - Total tuition fee (program): Unknown
  - Work Experience fee for the first semester: $500
  - Work Experience fee for the second semester: $500
- International Students: Visit International Fees and Related Costs page for more information.

Financial Assistance:
- OSAP funding is available for this program, provided the applicant meets eligibility criteria.

Admission Requirements:
- Ontario Secondary School Diploma or equivalent
- Grade 12 English (C or U)
- Grade 11 math (C, M or U) or grade 12 (C or U)
- Mature students may take the Admissions Assessment for English and math or upgrade to achieve required credits in English and math.
- Applicants may be required to have grades higher than the minimum requirements stated.

Course Exemptions:
- Information on transferring college and university credits can be found in the transfer guide.

English Language Proficiency:
- Proficiency in English communications is necessary for success in this program. Review English proficiency requirements for more information.

International Students:
- For more information regarding country-specific admissions, visit the International Admissions page.

Context:
International Students:
- Should visit the "International Admissions" page for country-specific admission requirements.
- Should apply through the George Brown College Online Application System.
- Can attend on-campus information sessions to have questions answered and learn about programs and career options.
- Can contact international recruitment representatives for inquiries, available for booking virtual meetings or submitting inquiries via the "International Contact Us" page.
- Can contact the Financial Aid Office for inquiries about OSAP, Bursaries, Scholarships, and other financial inquiries.
- Can make an appointment to see an Entry Advisor for advice on program options.
- Can contact the Centre for Business for general inquiries or specific inquiries related to programs and courses via email or phone.

Domestic Students:
- Should apply through Ontario Colleges.
- Can contact the Admissions Office for inquiries about admission requirements, deadlines, or the admissions process.

Contact Information:
- Domestic Student Admissions: admissions@georgebrown.ca or visit the Admissions section.
- International Student Admissions: Contact international recruitment representatives via booking a virtual meeting or submitting an inquiry on the "International Contact Us" page.
- Financial Aid Inquiries: FinAid@georgebrown.ca or visit the Financial Aid section.
- Centre for Business: business@georgebrown.ca, (416) 415-5000 ext. 2160.

Program-related Contact:
- Mario Pascucci, Program Co-ordinator for Business Administration (B145/155), mpascucc@georgebrown.ca.

Context: The program is offered at George Brown College's School of Management. The classes mainly take place at the St. James Campus, specifically at 200 King St. E. and 290 Adelaide St. E., Toronto, Ontario, Canada. International students can contact the college for more information through the International Contact Us page or by booking a virtual meeting or submitting an inquiry. Campus tours are offered regularly, and virtual tours are available. Interested individuals can sign up to receive tailored resources for their application process and learn more about the programs and life at George Brown College. The form requires the user to provide their first name, last name, email address, and indicate if they are domestic or international students along with their country.
